content.description: Climb thin finger crack just to the left of the prominent arete using only the crack- no stemming out left. Follow this up 10 feet, crux, and then make good moves on decent edges and horizontals to the top. Protects pretty well.
content.protection: Brass offsets down low, medium cams or tri-cams up higher.

content.description:
This route is not listed in the guide book.  However, knowingly is not a First Ascent, rather a "new" route.  In terms of "new", meaning not listed as route info has been lost through time, or very hard to find. 

  In the guide book, the route is to the right of route #6.  In between #6 and #7. 

  Just North of the Southern most mass of Stettner Rocks, there is a face divided into three by two large, four foot ledges.  Route height is approximately 25-30 feet, with a ledge at six feet, then again at 12 feet.  On the second ledge, there are two pine trees.  The route follows the crack approximately four to five feet to the left of the pine trees from the base to the top of the route.
content.protection: Follow far left hand crack over two large ledges.  Ledges are approximately 4 feet in width.  Medium to large pro for lead.

content.description: Scramble up a few blocks, follow inside corner until it ends, then finish last 10 feet on the face above the inside corner.
content.location: Located a few feet right of the section of rock face that is divided into 3 tiers by 2 large ledges. The inside corner is left of 2 large pine trees growing out of the rocks part way up the buttress.

content.description: Wide crack, crux is getting off the deck.  Nice short climb to work on fist jamming.
content.protection: Larger camalots (3 & up) and hexes for trad.
content.location: Opposite end of Stettner from the pinnacle with paul & joseph.  Route #16 in swartling & mayer's book

content.description: Southwest corner of Stettner Rocks.  There is a small overhang just to the left of the corner of the outcrop approximately 15 feet up.
content.protection:
Page 187 in Guidebook, Route #2: 

  Follow the hand crack under the small overhang.  Medium to Large pro for lead.  Follow crack and exit left of the overhang.  Far left corner of the rock formation

content.location: climb the right side of the rib for Paul.

content.description: The crux is about 10' up.  Past the crux it is a highway.  This a great route for new climbers.  There are nice ledges to rest upon.
content.location: Overhang at the southwest corner of the west buttress.  The route is to the left of Joseph.

content.description:
On the northern outcrop of Stettner Rocks.  At the south end of this outcrop, there are two small dihedrals, each about 5-6 feet deep.  This route follows the right/north dihedral, next to the pedestal. 

  Work up the dihedral and into the niche.  Reach or stem up to grab the edge to the left.  From here there are two finishes.  The 5.4/5.5 hand traverses straight left, around the corner and almost around the next corner again.  Once you have a good foot, clamber up. 

  The other finish stems straight up the crack.  Scum with your hip, and maybe even sit on the ledge!  This is about 5.7, and would be the most obvious way to lead this.
content.protection: Follow hand crack to "Niche" or small over hang.  Then exit to the left, via small hand traverse.  Medium pro for lead.

content.description:
This route is on the northern outcrop of Stettner Rocks, just to the right of "The Niche" (approximately five feet right).  There is a pedestal that forms a dihedral - the little dihedral at the start of the Niche.  Either start as for The Niche, or start on the outer corner, or start on the outer face of the pedestal to the right of a tree.  The latter two starts are about 5.7/5.8. 

  Once on this pedestal you are confronted by the Shelf.  Find a way to stand on this and the rest is easy!
this route starts just left of the brothers.Lots of steps,continue to chimney and up in crack to top.
content.protection: standard nut rack and small camseasy top rope

content.description: Very easy short climb. A good spot to take a first time climber, but thats about it. This is the front half of route #18 in the swartling book 3rd edition. I split #18 into 2 separate climbs (Front 9 and Back 9) because it just makes more sense to me, especially if top-roping them.
content.protection: Access for top-roping is easiest by scrambling up the rocks to the right from the bottom of Back 9.
content.location: This is located to the right of and somewhat separate from the Stettner Rocks crag proper. On the Northeast end of Stettners, follow the trail that continues NE for about 20 yards. Go through a narrow pass between 2 boulders and take a few more steps to the bottom of Front 9.

content.description: Nice corner past bulge at the start of Stettner Rocks.  Easy to set up anchors above and simple access route.  Only problem with the route is its short length.

Nice easy climb that has some height to it. Also, it can be climbed with several interesting variations from a single top rope anchor. This is the back half of route #18 in the swartling book 3rd edition. Great place for beginners, or anyone looking for an easy climb.
content.protection: Access for top-roping is easiest by scrambling up the rocks to the right from the bottom of Back 9.
content.location: This is located to the right of and somewhat separate from the Stettner Rocks crag proper. On the Northeast end of Stettners, follow the trail that continues NE for about 20 yards. Go through a narrow pass between 2 boulders and then look up the gully on the left.

content.description:
Refer to Area Descriptions - from above one level on MP:

 The guide book ("Climber's Guide to Devil's Lake by Swartling) states (P.186) "Starting from the cottage road, hike up the old West Bluff Trail 300 feet to a bench above the first minor rock band. On this level follow the path 100 feet northeast to base of Stettner Rocks."

 I had a hard time finding the old West Bluff Trail due to the heavy foliage, or perhaps, I just missed it. I followed the cottage road to approximately 100 feet before the first cottage, made a left, and went straight up the slope from the road. Approximately 200 feet from the road up. Also, from the West Bluff Parking lot, looking north along the West Bluff, a small part of Stettner Rocks can be seen peaking through the trees.
